item.title: India Ink: India and Pakistan Under Prime Minister Singh
item.description: Though the departing prime minister cannot point to any groundbreaking achievements, political analysts say his policy on Pakistan was pragmatic and saw moderate success despite some serious setbacks.
item.dc:creator: By KABIR TANEJA
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh worked for most of his 10-year tenure to build bridges with Pakistan.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 29
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Mayor Detained in Organized Crime Investigation
item.description: The arrest of the mayor, Arquímedes Oseguera, on Monday came a day after five people were killed on the outskirts of Lázaro Cárdenas when vigilante groups clashed with gunmen who they suspected were criminals.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Hospital Raid
item.description: Doctors Without Borders expressed outrage on Monday over the weekend killings of 16 civilians, including three staff members, on the property of a hospital it runs in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Ethiopia: 9 Media Workers Arrested
item.description: Nine bloggers and journalists were arrested in Addis Ababa last week just days before Secretary of State John Kerry’s scheduled visit to Ethiopia on Tuesday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Arc of a Failed Deal: How Nine Months of Mideast Talks Ended in Disarray
item.description: As a nine-month deadline for an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal passes, new punitive measures in progress and other moves could bring an intractable conflict to a new low.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority in Amman, Jordan, in March, one of their 34 meetings over nine months of negotiations.

item.title: Kerry Apologizes for Remark That Israel Risks Apartheid
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed support for Israel after a controversy erupted over a phrase he used in a private appearance.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Obama Defends Foreign Policy Against Critics
item.description: President Obama said his foreign policy was based on a workmanlike tending to American priorities that might lack the high drama of a wartime presidency but also avoided ruinous mistakes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and President Benigno S. Aquino III during a state dinner Monday night at Malacanang Palace in Manila.

item.title: U.S. Couple Denied Permission to Leave Qatar While Appeal is Pending
item.description: The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, were convicted last month of child endangerment in the death of their adopted daughter from Africa.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SHABINA S. KHATRI

item.title: One City Falls to Pro-Russian Militants; in Another, the Mayor Is Shot
item.description: Taken together, the events on Monday in Ukraine pointed to the further enfeeblement of the interim government in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian protesters marched in Donetsk on Monday after clashing with government supporters.

item.title: U.S. Expands Sanctions, Adding Holdings of Russians in Putin’s Financial Circle
item.description: The Obama administration ordered travel bans and asset freezes for seven Russian officials, including two said to be in Mr. Putin’s inner circle, and froze assets for 17 companies.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Lull Prompts Question: What Are Taliban Up To?
item.description: Officials in Afghanistan are urgently speculating about the absence of Taliban attacks since Election Day, suggesting the militants are biding their time, paralyzed by infighting, or worried about bad publicity.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan police officers in Kabul. Some officials suggest the Taliban have been less effective because security forces have improved.

item.title: Syria Announces Assad’s Bid for Re-election as War Rages
item.description: The election scheduled for June 3 is widely seen as an attempt to enhance President Bashar al-Assad’s perceived legitimacy despite the civil war that has displaced millions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Uproar in Egypt After Judge Sentences More Than 680 to Death
item.description: An Egyptian judge sentenced the spiritual leader of the Muslim Brotherhood and hundreds of others on charges of inciting or committing acts of violence.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Muslim Brotherhood supporters and relatives of those on trial reacting to the verdict in Minya, Egypt, on Monday.

item.title: Wounded Mayor Is Both Colorful and Powerful, Loved and Loathed
item.description: The shot that almost killed Mayor Gennady A. Kernes may yet prove fatal to Kharkiv as it seeks to maintain a fragile political balance in the weeks ahead without his guiding hand.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Gennady A. Kernes, the mayor of Kharkiv, Ukraine, on March 18 with members of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Mr. Kernes was shot in the back on Monday.

item.title: Results Are Promising in Clinical Trial of Dengue Fever Vaccine
item.description: Sanofi conducted a test of its vaccine for dengue fever, which affects 50 million to 100 million people annually, that involved 10,000 children in Southeast Asia.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: Welcome to the Haiyatt. In China, It’s Not the Hotel It Sounds Like.
item.description: Like many Chinese businesses with names and products closely resembling well-known international brands, hotels have come to see the value in borrowing the prestige of Western names.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE WEED
item.media:credit: Theodore Kaye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Haiyatt Garden Hotel in Guangdong Province. The hotel’s name resembles Hyatt less in Chinese characters.

item.title: Senate Drops Bid to Report on Drone Use
item.description: The provision was quietly stripped from an intelligence bill, highlighting continuing government resistance on these operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Finding a Flash Drive in the Sea
item.description: New technology will transform the way we track planes.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN ASHTON

item.title: Tehran Journal: Singer Steps Into Spotlight as Nation Changes Political Tune
item.description: Xaniar Khosravi was permitted to perform four concerts of his love songs in Iran in what was seen as a relaxation of cultural restrictions.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xaniar Khosravi, 29, performed in one of four concerts allowed him by Iran’s government. Mr. Khosravi’s upbeat style of music had long been deemed too Western.

item.title: Lawyers Say U.N. Aid Does Not Need Syria’s Consent
item.description: Thirty-five lawyers, including the United Nations former chief legal counsel, said the organization had been “overly cautious” in its aid deliveries.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Pakistani Says He Killed 3, Using Gay Site to Lure Them
item.description: The arrest of a man who has confessed to using the Internet to lure three murder victims has alarmed gay men and lesbians in Pakistan, where social media has quietly widened freedoms.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Muhammad Ejaz, held at a police station in Lahore, Pakistan, confessed to killing three men he had met on a social networking website for gay men.

item.title: Militants Pose Threat on Eve of National Elections in Iraq
item.description: The government appears powerless to control a jihadist group that insists on the power to indiscriminately kill Shiites.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Fighters from Al Qaeda patrolled in a commandeered Iraqi military vehicle in Falluja, west of Baghdad, on Sunday. Militants control wide areas in the provinces surrounding Baghdad.

item.title: Muslim Leaders Denounce Police Over Raids in Czech Capital
item.description: The publisher of a book said to incite violence and xenophobia was arrested, and 20 people were detained during Friday Prayer at a Prague mosque.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and JAN RICHTER

item.title: World Briefing: British Publicist Convicted of Indecent Assaults
item.description: Max Clifford, Britain’s best-known celebrity publicist, was found guilty of eight charges of indecent assault, including offenses dating back decades against women as young as 15.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
